headline: Meta shareholders seek sanctions for Sandberg, Zients for deleting Cambridge Analytica emails
summary: Attorneys for Meta shareholders asked a Delaware judge Monday to sanction the company's former Chief Operating Officer Sheryl Sandberg and fellow Facebook board member and current White House chief of staff Jeff Zients for deleting emails related to the Cambridge Analytica privacy scandal, despite being told to preserve such records.  The plaintiff attorneys contend that Sandberg and Zients used personal email accounts to communicate about key issues relating to their 2018 shareholder lawsuit that alleged Facebook officers and directors violated both the law and their fiduciary duties in failing for years to protect the privacy of user data.

raw.headline: Meta shareholders seek sanctions for Sandberg, Zients for deleting Cambridge Analytica emails
raw.summary: Attorneys for Meta shareholders asked a Delaware judge Monday to sanction the company's former Chief Operating Officer Sheryl Sandberg and fellow Facebook board member and current White House chief of staff Jeff Zients for deleting emails related to the Cambridge Analytica privacy scandal, despite being told to preserve such records. headline: Mag 7 'not critical' for market success in 2025: Strategist
summary: While Bloomberg Intelligence is forecasting the Magnificent Seven's earnings growth — Meta Platforms (META), Microsoft (MSFT), Alphabet (GOOGL, GOOG), Amazon (AMZN), Apple (AAPL), Nvidia (NVDA), Tesla (TSLA) — to drop from 2024's 34% to 18% in 2025, will the group of tech stocks be as pivotal for the S&P 500 (^GSPC) in the new year? "They're obviously important for the market, but they're not critical for the market's success. And we see signs that earnings growth is set to broaden out as we head into 2025," J.P. Morgan Private Bank US Head of Investment Strategy Jake Manoukian tells Seana Smith and Brad Smith on the Morning Brief. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief here. ]This post was written by Luke Carberry Mogan.

headline: Omnicom to Acquire Interpublic in Deal That Will Reshape Advertising Industry
summary: Omnicom  Group will acquire  Interpublic Group  in a deal that will create the world’s largest advertising business, the companies confirmed Monday.  A combined entity would have net revenue of more than $20 billion, based on 2023 figures for each company, and include storied ad agencies such as TBWA Worldwide and McCann Worldgroup.  The Wall Street Journal reported Sunday that the companies were in advanced merger talks.

raw.headline: Omnicom to Acquire Interpublic in Deal That Will Reshape Advertising Industry
raw.summary: Omnicom  Group will acquire  Interpublic Group  in a deal that will create the world’s largest advertising business, the companies confirmed Monday.  A combined entity would have net revenue of more than $20 billion, based on 2023 figures for each company, and include storied ad agencies such as TBWA Worldwide and McCann Worldgroup.  The Wall Street Journal reported Sunday that the companies were in advanced merger talks.

headline: Italy wraps up probe into two Meta execs on alleged $938 million VAT evasion by Facebook owner
summary: Italian prosecutors have wrapped up a probe into alleged tax evasion of 887.6 million euros ($937.93 million) by Facebook parent company Meta involving two executives of its Irish unit, the Milan prosecutor's office said on Monday.  Closing the investigation is the formal step before prosecutors file any requests for trial, unless the suspects have first proven their innocence.  While it is a modest sum for a company that brought in more than $32 billion in revenue last year, the case could have much wider ramifications for the industry as it hinges on the way Meta provides access to services such as Facebook and Instagram.

While it is a modest sum for a company that brought in more than $32 billion in revenue last year, the case could have much wider ramifications for the industry as it hinges on the way Meta provides access to services such as Facebook and Instagram.

headline: Mag 7's profit growth forecasted to slow in 2025: Bloomberg
summary: As the S&P 500's (^GSPC) Magnificent Seven — Meta Platforms (META) Microsoft (MSFT) Alphabet (GOOGL, GOOG), Amazon (AMZN), Apple (AAPL), Nvidia (NVDA), Tesla (TSLA) — could see its profit growth slow from 34% to 18% in 2025, Bloomberg Intelligence reports the healthcare sector could take the lead. Yahoo Finance host Madison Mills joins the Morning Brief to break down Bloomberg Intelligence's latest earnings growth estimates. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief here. This post was written by Luke Carberry Mogan.

headline: Interpublic Stock Soars on Omnicom Deal. Why It’s All About Meta and Google.
summary: Omnicom  and  Interpublic Group  appear to have decided that they’d be better off together as they try to stop Big Tech giants like  Alphabet  and  Meta Platforms  from eating their lunch.  The longtime rivals announced on Monday that Omnicom will buy Interpublic in a stock-for-stock transaction, creating the world’s largest advertising agency.  Under the terms of the deal, Omnicom shareholders will own 60.6% of the new combined company.

raw.headline: Interpublic Stock Soars on Omnicom Deal. Why It’s All About Meta and Google.

Under the terms of the deal, Omnicom shareholders will own 60.6% of the new combined company.

headline: Why this strategist is paying close attention to Nvidia & Meta
summary: U.S. stocks (^DJI,^GSPC, ^IXIC) gained after the November jobs report showed a strong picture of the U.S. economy. Now markets are pricing in about an 88% chance of a 25 basis-point rate cut at the December Fed meeting. Key Advisors Wealth Management CEO and co-founder Eddie Ghabour joins Catalysts Co-Hosts Seana Smith and Madison Mills to discuss how investors should position their portfolios with the Fed's next moves in mind. Ghabour is paying special attention to two Magnificent Seven stocks: Meta (META) and Nvidia (NVDA). "We're actually buying cyclicals. We've increased small caps. We've increased our exposure to Meta and Nvidia," Ghabour tells Yahoo Finance. While he is buying Nvidia now, Ghabour goes on to say that once things reach a peak, it will be one of the first names he sells. "When we start to see a top or what we believe is a top, we are going to sell the most aggressive holdings in the most highly owned holdings. We love Nvidia as a company and as a stock, but that will be one of the first things we cut because that will take a very big hit in our opinion." For more expert insight and the latest market action, click here to watch this full episode of Catalysts. This post was written by Cheyenne Reid.
